title: Luján Highlights $426,000 in Federal Funding for Emergency Watershed Protection

outline.text: Luján Highlights $426,000 in Federal Funding for Emergency Watershed Protection
Washington, D.C. – Congressman Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico’s Third District highlighted
more than $426,000 in federal funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) through
the Emergency Watershed Protection Program.  These funds help disaster recovery efforts and
are aimed at helping New Mexico in the wake of last year’s devastating fire season.
“Water is a precious resource that is essential to our way of life in New Mexico.  From safe and
reliable drinking water to water for our crops and livestock – protecting, restoring and ensuring
the vitality of our watersheds is critical, especially during these extreme drought conditions,”
Congressman Luján said.  “The wildfires in New Mexico over the past few years have
threatened to damage our watersheds and impact the daily life of our communities.  These
federal funds, which enhance our ability to protect and improve watersheds, are important to our
state and I will continue to support the Emergency Watershed Protection Program.”
New Mexico, one of 15 states allocated funding through the program, will receive $426,577 to
help implement recovery projects.  Examples of conditions qualifying for assistance include:
debris-clogged stream channels, undermined and unstable stream banks, jeopardized water
control structures and public infrastructures, and wind-borne debris removal.
